messages.subject: Re: Myochin Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: I photographed the Myochin tsuba. I need to invest in a better set- up for taking great pictures. I copied the Requirements for Tosogu Photographs article
messages.messageBody:
I photographed the Myochin tsuba. I need to invest in a better set-
up for taking great pictures. I copied the 'Requirements for Tosogu
Photographs' article and will work on purchasing the required items.
Anyway, you can find my photos in my 'photo album'. Hope they help.
I also included a picture of the 'Haki-Gaki'(sp).

Thanks,

Elliott

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Akasaka piece and musuem website.
messages.msgSnippet: Just back, at work, but later Akasaka workers did use soft metals. They were basically at the end of their greatness and were copying other works that had
messages.messageBody:
Just back, at work, but later Akasaka workers did use soft metals. They
were basically at the end of their greatness and were copying other
works that had taken the spotlight off them.

I will see what I can dig up when I pull my head out of the clouds. If
you have the Akasaka book, look towards the end of that.

Rich

messages.subject: Re: Akasaka piece and musuem website.
messages.msgSnippet: ... information.  A friend of mine has a daisho tsuba that is convex and entirely covered with full silver nunome.  There are also gold covered (uttori or
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Barry Thomas" <warlord@...> wrote:
>
> Milt,
>
> Even though this is more a private to you I put it to the list for
information. A friend of mine has a daisho tsuba that is convex and
entirely covered with full silver nunome. There are also gold covered
(uttori or nunome I'm not sure) symbols of good luck. These are
plainly Hizen tsuba, early Edo and EXCELLENT, although it could be said
that these also are "strange looking things". Could we please see some
GOOD pictures of your tsuba both sides, please, pretty please???
>
> Barry Thomas.
> aka Batman.
>
Herr Batmann,
I tried to upload the pics to my list album and get the message that "
I have no previlage to perform the function "..............
anyway, I sent the pics directly to your e-mail address........

bit#$, bit%$#, bit%$#$..........

Milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka piece and musuem website.
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, Even though this is more a private to you I put it to the list for information.  A friend of mine has a daisho tsuba that is convex and entirely covered
messages.messageBody:
Milt,

Even though this is more a private to you I put it to the list for information. A friend of mine has a daisho tsuba that is convex and entirely covered with full silver nunome. There are also gold covered (uttori or nunome I'm not sure) symbols of good luck. These are plainly Hizen tsuba, early Edo and EXCELLENT, although it could be said that these also are "strange looking things". Could we please see some GOOD pictures of your tsuba both sides, please, pretty please???

Barry Thomas.
aka Batman.

----- Original Message -----
From: MuramasaIII@...
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, October 25, 2006 12:53 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka piece and musuem website.


ken et al,
the nunome inlay thingie !!
There's an idea forward by some collectors that the sukashi tsuba were once
available with or without inlay as an " option " ( sort of like you want
racing stripes to go with your car ? ).Or may be they were added on later when
the samurai ( or merchants then )got tired of looking/feeling the
oleeeeeeeeee iron ? =)

I have two Kyo sukashi tsuba ( same design as the one in Sasano's book
)..........identical design, one has gold nunome ( traces of it ) and one without.

Also i recently bought a wak sukashi tsuba with full silver nunome
coverage..........strange looking thing.

milt
. _,___

messages.msgSnippet: ken et al, the nunome inlay thingie  !! There s an idea forward by some collectors that the sukashi tsuba were  once available with or without inlay as an
messages.messageBody:
ken et al,
the nunome inlay thingie !!
There's an idea forward by some collectors that the sukashi tsuba were once
available with or without inlay as an " option " ( sort of like you want
racing stripes to go with your car ? ).Or may be they were added on later when
the samurai ( or merchants then )got tired of looking/feeling the
oleeeeeeeeee iron ? =)

I have two Kyo sukashi tsuba ( same design as the one in Sasano's book
)..........identical design, one has gold nunome ( traces of it ) and one without.

Also i recently bought a wak sukashi tsuba with full silver nunome
coverage..........strange looking thing.

milt

messages.subject: Re: Akasaka piece and musuem website.
messages.msgSnippet: Ken I am hardly an expert but like you I am unawrae of Akasaka tsuba having gilt decoration.  That said, I am not sure I would put a lot of stock in this
messages.messageBody:
Ken
I am hardly an expert but like you I am unawrae of Akasaka tsuba
having gilt decoration. That said, I am not sure I would put a lot
of stock in this museum's kantei. The one link you posted shows a
dragon shaped tsuba that they describe as being Umetada- sure looks
Kinai to me. IOW don't let their Akasaka attribution upset your
applecart.
Kirk

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka piece and musuem website.
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, I found this musuem site that has a lot of tsuba pictured and I never had been to.  However they have this 17th Akasaka tsuba pictured that has a gold
messages.messageBody:
Hi all,

I found this musuem site that has a lot of tsuba
pictured and I never had been to. However they have
this 17th Akasaka tsuba pictured that has a gold
inlay. I didn't think that akasaka worked with
inlays? Is this just uncommon or wrong?
http://www.beloit.edu/~museum/wrightonline/exhibit6/e60012a.htm

Site is worth going through, some nice pieces,
begining of tsuba section:
http://www.beloit.edu/~museum/wrightonline/exhibit6/e60001a.htm

Thanks
Ken "the mantis dude"

__________________________________________________

messages.subject: Myochin Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Just a quick question..............Due to my great lack of being able to read Kanji, could someone in the group translate the Mei on my Myochin Tsuba? Go to
messages.messageBody:
Just a quick question..............Due to my great lack of being able
to 'read' Kanji, could someone in the group translate the Mei on my
Myochin Tsuba? Go to my photo album and scroll to the Myochin Tsuba,
click on it and tell me what it says.

Thank you for any help you can give me.

Elliott
